content.description:
The Opsimath climbs a bulging face on perfect Dakota sandstone.

Stand start with a left hand sidepull edge and a right hand sidepull jug. From there, reach up for an incut left hand edge, cross under to a sloper below the right hand, stick a left hand gaston out left, work the hands into place on the incut edges, get the feet up high on smears, and work the remaining diagonal shelf and subsequent top out.
content.protection: A pair of pads, one for the ground, and one maybe for the rock that sits behind the problem.
content.location: It climbs the center north face of Equinox.

content.description: Stand start with hands matched on the small rail just right of the rock. From there, move to a good left hand edge, follow with a right hand to a perfect mono pocket, then make a few big moves up and to the right on the incut edges to reach a solid topout.
content.protection: A pad or two will work well. The first move climbs very close to the rock, but it never really affected the climb in my experience.
content.location: It climbs the south face of Equinox.

content.description: Stand start with a left hand gaston and a right hand undercling.  From there, move up the slight overhang through a rough, right sidepull and pair of crimps to reach a slabby, solid topout.  The initial footwork is important, as it's key to reaching the crimp in a manner that doesn't destroy your fingers.
content.protection: A few pads and a spotter, the immediate landing for the problem is great.
content.location: This is on the North face of Equinox Boulder.
